results.title: Grace
results.brief_description: Returning from her adopted home in London, to attend the funeral of her sister, an Aboriginal woman finds herself isolated from both kin and culture. This emotionally mature and complex work moves beyond didactism and easily digestable polemics to suggest that cultural dislocation is written as much in the body, in language and the psyche as it is in economics and politics. By suggesting that the effects for the “stolen generation” were as destructive for inter-Aboriginal relationships as they were for black and white relations in this country, “Grace” is a devastating and confronting exploration of what it means to have been “stolen”.

results.title: Night cries: a rural tragedy
results.brief_description: In Tracey Moffatt’s re-imaging of the pivotal Australian film “Jedda”, a middle-aged Aboriginal woman returns to her outback home to nurse her dying white mother. Filmed against lushly coloured sets that recall the technicolour glories of the past, and utilising a harsh discordant soundscape, “Night Cries” occupies the landscape of dreams and the classic mythic terrain of familial violence and betrayal. This short film does more than simply reconfigure and re-imagine past narratives. It inaugurated a clear and permament break with previous moving image representations of the “outback”: no longer the pretence that it is a place outside language and history.

constellations_other.name: Indigenous futurisms
constellations_other.description: An exploration of works that put First Peoples futurisms first.

results.title: No way to forget
results.brief_description: Richard Frankland’s powerful short film based on his experiences as a lawyer on the Royal Commission on Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. A young Koorie man travelling the lonely highways of the Australian outback reflects on the tragic experiences of Aboriginal people in Australian prisons.

constellations_other.name: Black documentary and truth telling
constellations_other.description: Essie Coffey was a trailblazer of Indigenous filmmaking, being the first Aboriginal woman to direct a documentary. The film spotlights the outspoken voice Coffey utilised to convey the realities faced by Aboriginal people and to encourage resistance to assimilation.

results.description: Richard Frankland’s powerful short film based on his experiences as a lawyer on the Royal Commission on Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. A young Koorie man travelling the lonely highways of the Australian outback reflects on the tragic experiences of Aboriginal people in Australian prisons. A passionate and eloquent indictment of the entrenched racism in Australian legal culture.
description_for_label: Richard Frankland’s powerful short film based on his experiences as a lawyer on the Royal Commission on Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. A young Koorie man travelling the lonely highways of the Australian outback reflects on the tragic experiences of Aboriginal people in Australian prisons. A passionate and eloquent indictment of the entrenched racism in Australian legal culture.

results.title: Radiance (A)
results.creator_credit: Rachel Perkins, Andrew Myer, Ned Lander and Eclipse Films (Australia)
results.brief_description: Three sisters are reunited after the death of their mother; their lifestyles a world apart from each other. Eldest sister Cressy (Rachael Maza), has found success as a classical singer and rejected her past life to pursue a career overseas. Middle daughter Mae (Trisha Morton-Thomas) resents Cressy’s success and feels bitter at being the one whose had to stay behind to care for their senile mother. Youngest sister Nona (Deborah Mailman), is vibrant, sexually promiscuous, pregnant, and unlike her sisters, loyal to the memory of their mother. In the brief time the sisters spend together, they learn the painful memories and secrets that has distanced them from one another, and as the family’s intrigue is revealed the sisters can finally unite together.

results.title: Dust [Widescreen] (A)
results.creator_credit: Ivan Sen, Teresa-Jayne Hanlon, Autumn Films, New South Wales Film and Television Office and Special Broadcasting Service Corporation
results.brief_description: 2 cars arrive at a desolate cotton property. One car carries two feuding white teenagers Amy (Nathalie Roy) and Mick (Tristan Bancks)- the other 2 aboriginal youths Leroy (Clayton Munro) and Vance (Wayne Munro) and an elderly aboriginal woman called Ruby (Peta Binge). Under the fast moving clouds a storm is brewing, and when racism reaches a head and the dust storm finally erupts, the 5 find themselves confined in a car where they can no longer flee the tragedy of the past. Nominated for three AFI awards, Ivan Sen’s final film received a special commendation at the Clermonth Ferrand Short Film Festival.

results.title: Acquiring a taste for Raffaella
results.creator_credit: Sandra Lepore, Fotini Manikakis and AFTRS
results.brief_description: The onset of menstruation leads to a curious mix of events when Raffaella shares the news with her traditional Italian Aunt. Together they make some special Italian love biscuits, “biscotti di amore”, with a secret ingredient intimately linked with Raffaella’s menarche. When the object of her affections tastes the love biscuits, surprisingly, he asks for the recipe.

results.title: Journey (A)
results.creator_credit: Ivan Sen and ABC-TV (Australia). Indigenous Program Unit
results.brief_description: A twelve year old boy leaves his isolated home town hitchhiking across a forever changing landscape. His travels cause him to relive fragments of the life left behind as he struggles to find rest in a journey that may never end.

results.title: Shifting Sands: from sand to celluloid continued...(A)
results.brief_description: This video contains six short films about the lives of Aboriginal Australians living in today’s society. “Tears”, directed by Ivan Sen, is the story of a teenage couple as they walk from their northern mission station to a bus stop and await a new life with the girl’s father, who perhaps doesn’t know they are coming and who probably doesn’t care anyway. “My colour, your kind”, directed by Danielle McLean, is the journey through and to uncertainty of an albino Aboriginal girl who escapes from a severe Catholic mission to trek barefoot in a nightie across the outback. “Passing through”, directed by Mark Olive, a young family on their way to visit relatives pass through an old gold mining town. As the woman begins to delve into memories of her childhood, the family leave to continue their journey. Has she missed the opportunity to discover the secrets of the past? “Promise”, directed by Mitch Torres, is the tale of an old woman overseeing her grand-daughter making damper when she is asked how it came to be that she was betrothed at a young age. “My bed, your bed”, directed by Erica Glynn, in an isolated desert community, the time has come for two young people promised to each other under traditional law to move in together. Things don’t run as smoothly as they might. “Grace”, directed by Wesley Enoch, Grace is a middle-aged woman, living a comfortable life but when she returns to the mission where she grew up for the funeral of her sister she is confronted by the family she never met.

results.title: After Mabo (A)
results.creator_credit: John Hughes, Debra Annear, Richard Frankland and Mirimbiak Nations Aboriginal Corporation
results.brief_description: Filmed over a ten-month period throughout Australia, this probing documentary examines the political controversy surrounding Native Title and the Australian Federal Governments proposed amendments to the Native Title Act, 1993. It follows the Indigenous representatives in their attempt to fight the amendments in the media, in the bush, and in the halls of Parliament House, Canberra. This video is ideally suited to students of history, politics and Aboriginal studies. NOTE: There are no discussion notes included with this title.

results.title: No way to forget (A)
results.brief_description: Based on Richard Frankland’s experiences as a field officer during the Royal Commission into Aboriginal custody, this film follows the journey of Shane as he drives from Swan Hill to Melbourne after a day in the field. During the night, his experiences play on his mind and imagination. He will be haunted by what he has seen.
